item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: Far far away, behind the word mountains, far from the countries Vokalia and Consonantia, there live the blind texts. Separated they live in Bookmarksgrove right at the coast of the Semantics, a large language ocean. A small river named Duden flows by their place and supplies it with the necessary regelialia. It is a paradisematic country, in which roasted parts of sentences fly into your mouth. Even the all-powerful Pointing has no control about the blind texts it is an almost unorthographic life One day however a small line of blind text by the name of Lorem Ipsum decided to leave for the far World of Grammar. The Big Oxmox advised her not to do so, because there were thousands of bad Commas, wild Question Marks and devious Semikoli, but the Little Blind Text didn’t listen. She packed her seven versalia, put her initial into the belt and made herself on the way. When she reached the first hills of the Italic Mountains, she had a last view back on the skyline of her hometown Bookmarksgrove, the headline of Alphabet Village and the subline of her own road, the Line Lane. Pityful a rethoric question ran over her cheek, then…

If this be error and upon me proved, let me not to the marriage of true minds I never writ, nor no man ever loved. Within his bending sickle’s compass come; or bends with the remover to remove. Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks, that looks on tempests and is never shaken; which alters when it alteration finds. Whose worth’s unknown, although his height be taken. Or bends with the remover to remove. It is the star to every wand’ring bark, love’s not time’s fool, though rosy lips and cheeks which alters when it alteration finds.

item.title: Welcome

item.content:encoded: The quick, brown fox jumps over a lazy dog. DJs flock by when MTV ax quiz prog. Junk MTV quiz graced by fox whelps. Bawds jog, flick quartz, vex nymphs. item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: She packed her seven versalia, put her initial into the belt and made herself on the way. When she reached the first hills of the Italic Mountains, she had a last view back on the skyline of her hometown Bookmarksgrove, the headline of Alphabet Village and the subline of her own road, the Line Lane. Pityful a rethoric question ran over her cheek, then she continued her way. On her way she met a copy. The copy warned the Little Blind Text, that where it came from it would have been rewritten a thousand times and everything that was left from its origin would be the word “and” and the Little Blind Text should turn around and return to its own, safe country. But nothing the copy said could convince her and so it didn’t take long until a few insidious Copy Writers ambushed her, made her drunk with Longe and Parole and dragged her into their agency, where they abused her for their projects again and again.

item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: A wonderful serenity has taken possession of my entire soul, like these sweet mornings of spring which I enjoy with my whole heart. I am alone, and feel the charm of existence in this spot, which was created for the bliss of souls like mine. I am so happy, my dear friend, so absorbed in the exquisite sense of mere tranquil existence, that I neglect my talents. I should be incapable of drawing a single stroke at the present moment; and yet I feel that I never was a greater artist than now. When, while the lovely valley teems with vapour around me, and the meridian sun strikes the upper surface of the impenetrable foliage of my trees, and but a few stray gleams steal into the inner sanctuary, I throw myself down among the tall grass by the trickling stream; and, as I lie close to the earth, a thousand unknown plants are noticed by me: when I hear the buzz of the little world among the stalks, and grow familiar with the countless indescribable forms of the insects and flies, then I feel the presence of the Almighty, who formed us in his own image, and the breath…

item.title: Firewood and Timber

item.content:encoded: All of our wood is from the South Downs, sustainably sourced and respectfully gathered, see if you are in our free firewood delivery area or check out the timber we have seasoning.

item.title: Woodland Crafts
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: Broad Leaves makes and can supply many traditional woodland products including: Post and rail fencing. Chestnut roof shingles. Struts strainers and stakes. Hedging stakes. Treen such as chopping boards, bowls, spoons etc. Please phone 07890413869 for availability.

item.title: Tree Surgery
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: We have been working with trees in Brighton and Lewes for over fifteen years carrying out reducing and thinning operations and felling dead, diseased or dangerous trees. As technical members of the arboricultural association we carry out tree work to the highest standards with full public liability and NPTC trained staff. Mr. Antony Lucas is employed as a technical assessor for the NPTC, the body that trains operators in chainsaw usage and arboriculture. We also will give free quotes and advice. Telephone 07890 413869 or send an email.

item.title: Forestry
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: We have a small but growing forestry contractor business with over twelve years experience in broadleaved lowland woodlands and upland coniferous plantation forestry. Contracts have included clearing rides and tracks, thinning to a return for woodland owners and to create optimal timber quality. We are currently thinning wood for firewood which has been suppressed by the desired timber crop trees and coppicing overstood sweet chestnut for the Norfolk Estate in West Sussex. We take on felling for land owners, companies and private individuals, this includes small thinning extraction to felling large timber trees and have 5 million pounds public liability insurance when working in forestry or tree surgery. We also offer a selectively felling  service within woodlands to minimise disruption when taking out valuable timber trees. Please ring 07890413869 for forestry services.

item.title: Welcome to Broad leaves
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded:
Hello and welcome to Broad leaves. We are a Lewes based company actively promoting the care of woodlands and trees, this includes tree work (Arboriculture), woodland management, ecological surveying and management, restoration and care of forests and hedgerows.
We specialise in creating management plans for small woodlands in the South East of England and carrying out vegetation surveys of woodlands from mosses to ground flora to canopy layer.
Although our background is based in woodland management and ecology we also provide timber and woodland products such as logs, planks and fencing products often straight from the coppice.

item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: He must have tried it a hundred times, shut his eyes so that he wouldn’t have to look at the floundering legs, and only stopped when he began to feel a mild, dull pain there that he had never felt before. “Oh, God”, he thought, “what a strenuous career it is that I’ve chosen! Travelling day in and day out. Doing business like this takes much more effort than doing your own business at home, and on top of that there’s the curse of travelling, worries about making train connections, bad and irregular food, contact with different people all the time so that you can never get to know anyone or become friendly with them.

item.content:encoded: Currently milling timber and waiting for it to season Ash, Oak, Sweet Chestnut and unusual hard woods Contact us for further information.

item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: For new and existing woodland owners we offer a comprehensive woodland ecological survey/ 5 year Woodland Management Plan service. This includes: Habitat surveys. Woodland NVC classification surveys of ground flora, shrub layer and tree species. Dormice, bat and other woodland mammal detection surveys. Timber volume estimation (mensuration). Prospective yield. Mapping rides and compartments. Felling/ thinning/ re-stocking plans. Ride management plans. Felling Licence application and TPO form filling. Grant application and funding. Get in touch for further details and a tailor made service.

item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: Sweet chestnut is a highly versatile hardwood ideal for outside constructions such as pergolas and fencing. This is due to a high tannin content in the heartwood, these compounds preserve the wood so that its remains rot resistant when used above or below ground. Chestnut posts will outlast treated softwood posts without the need to boil the wood in environmentaly damaging chemicals. We cut chestnut from October onwards and take specific product length orders from October to December. Normally the trees are cut for specific products. Throughout most of the year we have a limited supply of: 6’6″ Split post and rail posts. (not morticed). 9’6″ Rails for post and rail fencing (ended to order). 10′ Pergola poles. 7′ Straining posts. 5’6″ Posts (rounds, half rounds, quarter rounds). 5′ Tree stakes.

item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: We are proud to be a approved supplier of ‘The Hobbit’ wood burning stove – a small cast iron stove with airwash and cleanburn – £485rrp inc VAT. Please email or telephone 0789413869 for more information and we will be pleased to answer any questions. The Hobbit Designed by engineers and handmade by craftsmen, this little cast iron multi fuel stove is at the pinnacle of stove design. Compact proportions make it the ideal choice for a canal boat. The Hobbit incorporates patented turboblaze technology, ensuring excellent clean burning and glass airwash efficiency. The dual turboblaze secondary combustion chambers fitted inside each hobbit stove ensure that the maximum energy potential of every log or lump of coal is harnessed. Hobbit Installations can include a variety of scenarios and the compact nature of the stove makes it ideal for stove installations where space is restricted. The stove is a complimentary blend of traditional elegance and modern styling. The clean lines making it suitable for a wide range of decor situations. Many traditional small fireplaces, especially those converted to gas, need widening to incorporate a wood stove. The small footprint of the Hobbit means that this stove can be installed into a…

item.title: Planting and Preservation
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: The winter months are busy for us as we are often planting trees for new woodlands, hedges and creating orchards.This is often for habitat connectivity as part of landscape scale restoration. We pride ourselves in the fact that we plant many more trees than we fell, (over 3000 planted last year). The rapid demise of the British hedgerow since the since the second world war in the South of England and East Anglia due to the industrialisation of agriculture is shocking as more hedges are grubbed out or become more and more gappy due to neglect. This fragmentation of our wildlife connectivity is an issue that charities such as The Wildlife Trusts are work hard to raise public awareness. We quote planting hedges on a metre basis and can offer the best advice for species mix on your soil type and locatiuon. We use the best quality stock from specialist nurseries to help with establishment success.

Get in touch for further details and a tailor made service.

item.title: Coppice Work
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: Coppicing is a traditional form of woodland management that has been undertaken in Britain for thousands of years, evidence from sites such as the Sweet Track on the Somerset Levels and Seahenge in Norfolk have shown that coppicing has been practiced as a form of sustainable woodland mangement since the Bronze Age. Coppicing involves cutting trees to grond level leaving the stool or stump, from which new shoots grow to be cut again at the end of the coppice rotation. This rotation can be quite short or long depending on the products required. There are many ground flora and invertebrate species that are well suited to coppice systems because by its nature coppice opens up the ground to light for a few years before the shoots crowd over once again. It is because of this intermediate disturbance, the longer a woodland has been coppiced the more species rich and diverse a woodland becomes. Unfortunately most previously coppiced woodlands are not managed at all and biodiversity has suffered dramatically, therefore we actively promote coppicing and tree selection felling as viable and ecological forms of woodland management. We are currently looking for more derelict  or overgrown coppices to manage. Previous clients include : The Forestry Commission, Brighton and Hove Council and The Norfolk Estate. We believe that coppice is a gift from previous foresters that has been placed in our care, we similarly leave it for the next generation. We will only work woodlands for the preservation and restoration of woodland ecosystems and, as much as possible to improve woodlands by creating a viable future timber resource.

item.title: Green Wood Furniture
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: No wood is ever wasted at Broad Leaves , we would rather make beautiful objects first before making a tree into fuel! We make turnery and treen using green woodwork crafts such as turning bowls on pole lathes and using shave horses to make chair legs and seats. We are learning from the master himself: Mike Abbot at Brockhouse Wood. If you would like to earn from Mike here is his website www.living-wood.co.uk. commissions under taken.

We carry out hedge laying during the winter months and on a metre price. Please phone or email us for details.

item.title: Logs
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded: We deliver cubic metre loads within a ten mile drive from our wood yard near Lewes. All logs are sourced within the South Downs and from sustainably managed coppice. We can cater for wood burners with small grates with our sweet chestnut logs. They are particularly suited to wood burners because they burn hot but can spark a bit. We also have a limited supply of pub logs and hardwood logs for open fires. 1metre loads of wood burner logs are 50 pounds delivered. 1 metre loads of hardwood logs are 60 pounds delivered. Call 07890 413869 or enquire via email.

item.title: A January Day in Stanmer Park
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded:
Millbank Wood 19th January 2010. I am lying on the forest floor, the mist has shifted off the downs and the January sun casts a faint candle to the grey kindling trunks of standing ash. It is lunch time my workmate has left me to find his forgotten lunch box. I can hear the put put of the little red tractor as it struggles in the snow and ice, barely in his control down towards Stanmer Village.
As I look through the canopy of the remaining trees I can see what we have created. The straight Ash stems sway like seaweed on the bottom of a deep blue ocean floor their benthic forms have found new freedoms and they test this by swaying clockwise and anti clockwise in the slow current. This wood was knocked for six in the 87, winded the life out of the beeches that Richard Jeffries held so dear in one night, their smooth female forms lay prostrate against the cold ground with their root plates standing like chalk clad grave stone markers.
Two buzzards cry and interrupt my thoughts as I begin the traditional woodsman’s fayre of pot noodle cooked by the storm kettle. This, after talking at length in the morning about the sanctity and holiness of the humble russet I finish off with a nondescript supermarket apple. The dog does not eat the core.
Future foresters will thank us for this, just as we are thanking the team of people who replanted the beeches after the 87, now freed from their suppression of 23 years, we are the first to tend them, we prune them and make them straight as though we are giving them a quick pep talk “straighten up chaps, stand tall”. The ash we have singled out are often 30 feet to the first branch, these will be proud sentinels in fifty or so years time, dead straight grained thinned before the main event when the beech covers the sky here. Shallow chalks and beeches on this once downland ridge once more.
Put. Put! The tractor returns, the public enter the woods a tribe of wild eyed children are released along the path shouting like pirates through the trees. The dog looks at me, alarmed, they are more feral than he now, and we both look towards the tractor hoping for biscuits.

item.title: Sneaking up on Snowdon
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded:
In the Cwm Bychan, a sessile oak woodland has followed the rushing stream from the foothills of Snowdonia down to Llanaber since the end of the last ice age. The village itself is comparatively recent, the oldest sign of habitation here is a pagan spiral incised stone which sits quietly minding its own business between the altar and a jug of daffodils in the quaint village church.
There is nothing like sessile oak Atlantic woodlands in spring. They grow on the steep moisture laden sites that have escaped the plough or the sheep. These mysterious woodlands are home to rare bryophytes and ferns who relish the damp conditions.
I came to see them in spring, spring has started in the south east, the oaks had flushed for a week outside my house and ash was just bursting into leaf as I left. But here in the mountains, oak is just purpling its buds and so I am treated to a double spring. The trees burst forth again and underfoot are bluebells of the most perfect form. Amongst other plants, the rhapsody of woodland flora seems to begin with lesser celandine with its yellow flowers followed by wood anemone and then greater stitchwort.
I saw these woodland collections today on the Llyn peninsula. These cheeky customers were not content to just be confined to woodland habitats, they boldly go about their business in the coastal fields. Disappointingly close though lurk the pendulous storm of rhododendron that subsumes all before it until only the occasional individual hangs on along roadsides and paths.
These woodland flora are most radiant at this time because they have co-evolved to flower just before leaf burst in the tree canopy. This is done to optimise the photosynthesising time before the canopy draws its curtain of leaves across the window to the light.
The woods of Cwm Bychan have performed this synchronised dance for millennia, the plants that attempt to emerge earlier are beaten by harsh frosts and the plants that are late can not capture enough sunlight to prosper. By this means only the punctual survive, thus the yearly equilibrium is maintained each year growing more perfect.

item.title: Sweet chestnut coppice products

item.content:encoded:
Sweet chestnut is a highly versatile hardwood ideal for outside constructions such as pergolas and fencing. This is due to a high tannin content in the heartwood, these compounds preserve the wood so that its remains rot resistant when used above or below ground. Chestnut posts will outlast treated softwood posts without the need to boil the wood in environmentaly damaging chemicals.
We cut chestnut from October onwards and take specific product length orders from October to December. Normally the trees are cut for specific products.

item.title: Woodland management for domouse conservation (paper)
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded:
Antony Lucas, Bsc. Hons (Ecology), FdSc. (Forestry and Woodland Management). Tech ArborA.   NOTE: Figures and tables are missing from this extract. An Evaluation of Dormice (Muscardinus avellanarius) Survey Methods and Management Practices in the U.K.   Introduction. The common or hazel dormouse (M. avellanarius) is a native species in Britain. Although it is widely known about, it is rarely seen without the aid of specialist equipment. Dormice are found throughout Europe and regions of Asia (Morris 2003), however in the U.K. within the last 100 years there has been an alarming contraction in the overall spread of the species (Miller and Yahnke 2004). At present they have a relative stronghold in the south of England, have become extinct in Scotland and Ireland and are extremely rare in Wales. There are also isolated clusters of dormice communities in Cumbria and Northumberland (Morris 2003). This decline has been attributed to a combination of different reasons: habitat fragmentation/loss and changing climate (warmer wetter winters) being the most damaging (Morris 2003). The latter, in relation to dormice is important to scientists because of the specialist nature of these animals; their inability to adapt to change makes them important indicators as to how other species may respond to a rapid change in climate (Appendix A has an overview of the unique traits of the common dormouse). This paper is concerned with assessing the effectiveness of the techniques used to identify the presence of dormice and strategies employed to assist their conservation.     Discussion.   1. Dormouse recognition.   It is important to know firstly if dormice are present within an area and if so, how many individuals are present from year to year. Further monitoring can then be undertaken.   1a. Woodland suitability. Dormice are not adapted to all woodland environments,Table 1 (taken from Natural England interim guidance document) summarises woodland features that are useful in identifying woodland suitability for dormice; knowing these habitat features and enhancing them by careful management can increase dormice populations.   Table 1. Favourable and Unfavourable Habitat Features for Dormice (Anon, N.E, F.C. 2007).  
Favourable habitat features   Unfavourable features  
• Woods that are connected to other areas of suitable woodland. • Wide range of broadleaved species and ages present, in patches, scattered throughout, or around the edge • Shrub layer present, especially with hazel, honeysuckle or bramble • Species-rich scrub on woodland margins, ride-sides or in patches • Canopy connections across tracks or thick, wide hedgerow connections to other nearby suitable habitat • Conifer/broadleaved mixtures or conifer plantations colonised by native broadleaves • Fruiting hazel or sweet chestnut – ideally as managed coppice.   • Small isolated wood or adjacent only to an older conifer plantation • Plantation already subjected to several traditional rack thinnings • Densely shaded with little or no understorey • Signs of deer/stock eating regenerating trees/shrubs, or lack of regeneration • Preponderance of waterlogged ground in winter • History of clearfelling of large coupes relative to the woodland area • Absence of large fruiting trees • Plantations lacking any native broadleaved trees and shrubs i.e. ‘cleaned’ conifers • Crops from which all nurse conifers have been removed in one operation • Sites above 300m altitude • Short rotation (<7 yrs) coppice in cycle.  
  Table 1 enables woodland owners and conservation groups to assess the suitability of a woodland, however it has been noted by the author that woodlands thought ideal for dormice harbour little or none of these animals and other woodlands that are thought of as more unsuitable do show dormouse presence.   1b. National surveys. In order to assess the national state of dormice there have been a number of surveys undertaken in the U.K. Elaine Hurell oversaw the first in the mid 1970s when it was revealed that dormice had probably become extinct in seven counties where they had been noted a century earlier (Morris 2003) and it was not clear why dormouse distribution ranges had contracted to half their geographical range. Elaine Hurell and her father had first noted that dormice open hazel nuts in a particular way due to their unique molar teeth (see Appendix A). They turn the nut sideways and use their molars to scoop a hole in the side to extract the contents. The resulting hole is smooth lined and very noticeable when compared to the more ragged teeth marks left by other rodents. This discovery enabled dormice presence to be detected even though the animals may never be seen; however this does not tell the observer in what numbers the dormice may be present.   The generally accepted method proving the presence or absence of dormice is as follows (Morris 2004):  
  • Search 3 5x5 square metre plots for 20 minutes underneath hazel bushes.
  • Repeat the test 5 times in different locations within the woodland. If there is no evidence of dormouse-opened nuts, it is thought that dormice are not present within the woodland.
  The activity is easy to do and with the right person checking hazel nuts at a centralised location, distribution maps of dormice presence can be drawn. There have been a number of ‘nut hunts’; the largest was a countrywide exercise in 1993 known as the ‘Great Nut Hunt’ where 6,000 members of the public were issued with information sheets explaining what to look for and a form to fill out detailing how they carried out their experiment. 1,352 hazel nuts proved to have been opened by dormice, which allowed a specialist team to locate 334 dormouse sites in England and Wales. From these a new distribution map was created. Although hazel nut surveys do not show how abundant dormice are within the woodland, they are useful because, as dormice are a European protected species, noting the presence of these animals justifies further measures to monitor their status.   Problems arise with the Great Nut Hunt and other similar nationwide schemes in creating accurate distribution maps. As the schemes are voluntary, (that is undertaken by interested parties throughout the U.K.) rather than compulsory (for all woodland owners who own suitable woodlands), the overall spread of woodlands surveyed will be uneven. Woodlands surveyed are more likely to be those that are in public ownership or open access and distributed near areas where people are interested in dormice. Woodlands that are more inaccessible and in private ownership which may have healthy dormice numbers may be poorly represented on the resulting distribution maps. Other problems from the Great Nut Hunt included poor record keeping and grid referencing with one new dormouse woodland being located in the North Sea (Morris 2004).   2. Dormouse Monitoring.   2a. Trapping. Until recently the use of mammal traps such as Longworth traps were thought of as unsuitable in studying dormice (Bright and Morris 1994). Bright and Morris (1993) estimated (by nestboxes and radio tracking) that the density of dormice in diverse low-growing woodland is on average 12 individuals per hectare and 6 individuals in coppice with standards (it was not stated whether these figures included juveniles). These results may have been misleading as it is known that densities increase due to the use of nestboxes (Berg and Berg 1999) (see below). Trapping programmes in Sweden in 1999 have now proved that trapping is a useful technique in estimating the size of dormice populations within a given area; it has also proven useful in recording the range and survival rate of marked individuals. Furthermore, the Swedish experiments showed that contrary to earlier experiments (Bright and Morris 1990), dormice can be recaptured and in some cases are actively attracted to traps. The results can be transferred to U.K. dormice as they are from a habitat that is similar to southern English low coppiced hazel/oak woodland (although there was proportion of Norway spruce in its species make up). The experiment involved catching dormice in Jarnia 9x9x26cm rodent traps at a height of 1.5-2m above ground on forked branches at 20m intervals within the shrub layer. The traps were checked every morning during three consecutive trapping nights between May and September; trapped dormice were fur clipped for identification, weighed and sexed. The Swedish experiments have shown that 175 trap nights were needed to trap most of the adults within a hectare area and it was estimated that dormice densities were 7 (6.7) individuals in a hectare with an adult survival rate of between 56%-74% (Berg and Berg 1999). The range results were broadly similar to Bright and Morris’ (1992) results in that it was discovered the average range was 0.5ha, assuming a circular range shape. Berg and Berg’s experiment also showed that the ideal density of traps were at 20m rather than 10m spacings. The 20m spacings showed no loss of trapping efficiency and trapping rates were considerably higher later in the season thus the number of trap nights required could be reduced when trapping at this time of year.   2b. Nestboxes.   During the warmer months of the year dormice nest in hollow trees and brambles however they prefer to use nestboxes if provided with them (Morris 2004). Dormouse nest boxes are now the best way of studying dormouse biology and ecology (Morris 2004); in fact, since their introduction it was noted that dormice prefer to use nestboxes (85% of a population in a radio tracking study carried out by Bright and Morris, 1991). Initially it was thought that frequent disturbance of nests in order to collect data from the dormice may distress the nesting animals unduly. This was proven not to be the case by Bright and Morris and subsequent monitoring. Disturbing the nests caused one third of the dormice to depart (but only to an adjacent nest site), another third disappeared temporarily and one third remained unaffected (Bright and Morris 1990). Experiments conducted in 2005 demonstrated that the introduction of nestboxes into a woodland in Poland where dormice are present doubled their density (Juskaitis 2005). This effect became apparent after the first year of the introduction. Initially it was shown that this was due to immigration from areas without nestboxes, however in the second and third years there was a large and sustained increase in the survival of dormice within the control area and an increase in mature dormouse range (Juskaitis 2005). Nestboxes are therefore a non-disruptive way to easily survey dormice and are beneficial for their populations. Where dormice populations have been measured, measurement must continue with data being sent to the National Dormouse Monitoring Scheme. This enables treatments to the site such as coppice work or hedgerow planting to be monitored. Publications by Natural England and the Forestry Commission are then updated to show which treatments to a site affect dormouse survival (Anon, N.E, F.C. 2007). (Appendix B lists the factors to consider when planning forestry operations). Juskaitis’ experiments have introduced the idea that one of the limiting factors for dormice within a woodland is a lack of suitable nest sites such as tree holes. Dormice numbers (over time) become dependent on nestboxes; it is fundamentally important that where nestboxes are introduced, they should not be removed, the result would be a large drop in dormouse populations within the area.   2c. Radio Tracking. Radio tracking is a useful tool in determining dormouse movements and ranges (Bright and Morris 1990). The data gathered from these experiments has proved very useful in prescribing management plans for the conservation of these animals. Experiments with radio tracking of dormice in 1988 in Somerset (U.K.) have shown that dormice will take considerable detours rather than cross open ground and that ranging behaviour changes as seasons progress due to changing food availability (Bright and Morris 1990). This unwillingness to cross open ground has far-reaching impacts on management and re-introduction work (see below). Bright and Morris used radio tracking to show that dormice do not leave their nests during inclement weather (Bright and Morris 1990); this may, at first seem trivial but if dormice are not leaving their nests in wet weather, they will not mate. One of the most important discoveries was that male ranges of dormice overlap females but not other males (Bright and Morris 1990). This has implications for re-introductions; it would be safe to assume that re-introducing multiple males with multiple females may not be the best policy. Table 2 demonstrates how dormice sexes overlapped with each other in the 1988 study by Bright and Morris. It is clear that males do not overlap in the breeding season.   Table 2. Overlaps of 28 dormice tracked in 1988, columns show the overlap between male ranges, between female ranges and between male and female ranges. Mean %area for overlap was only calculated for areas that did overlap (from Bright and Morris 1990).  
  Male / Male Female / Female. Male / Female.
No. of possible overlaps No. of actual overlaps % frequency of overlap % mean area of overlap % mean area of overlap in breeding season   28 4 14 18   0 62 16 25 15   17 44 17 38 39   39
                          3. Management Practices and legal protection.   3a. Legal protection.   The dormouse is a European protected species under the European Habitats Directive 1994 (2007). The Habitats Directive* aims to conserve various species of plant and animal which are known to be rare across Europe; it requires member states to provide legal protection for these species (Anon, N.E, F.C. 2007). Many of the species within woodlands are European Protected Species (EPS) including great crested newts, sand lizards, otters, bats and dormice (Anon, N.E, F.C. 2007). The E.U. directive was made British law in 1994 and amended in 2007. The amendment removed the defence of ‘incidental result’ (Anon, N.E, F.C. 2007). This meant that it is now an offence to damage EU species habitats or individuals deliberately or by accident. Landowners or agents following Natural England/Forestry Commission guidance should demonstrate that all reasonable steps have been taken when carrying out management activities that may harm dormice within woodlands (Anon, N.E, F.C. 2007). There is an inherent problem with complying with E.U. habitat directive guidelines: habitats require management in order to conserve rare species but this management may contravene the rigorous protection that the directive requires  (Anon, N.E, F.C. 2007). This problem is addressed by the EU in the form of a statement that member states should ‘offer flexibility i.e.: while recognising that absolute protection for all individuals of a species cannot be  guaranteed, ensure that any harmful action takes full account of the conservation needs of the species/population concerned’ (Anon, N.E, F.C. 2007). The 2007 amendment should prove to be very effective in dormouse conservation if people are successfully prosecuted when damaging dormouse habitats. The E.U. Habitats Directive must be seen to ‘have teeth’ to be effective. *Formal title: Council Directive 92/4/EEC on the conservation of natural habitats and of wild fauna and flora.     3b. Practices thought to be beneficial for woodlands with dormice. Suggestions for appropriate methods of woodland management have been published by Bright and Morris (1989, 1994, 2003). They are shown in table 3 below (Figure 5 shows a prediction of this management may improve dormouse ranges in Herefordshire).       Table 3. Beneficial woodland management practices for conserving dormice.  
Overstorey Tall trees should be thinned to encourage a strong and dense understorey growth.
Understorey Coppicing of hazel should be carried out on 15-20 year rotations in small coup sizes.
Gaps within the canopy Arboreal access should be maintained and encouraged as dormice will rarely cross open ground and will take long detours through the tree canopy to avoid crossing even very short distances on the ground. This was shown by radio tracking experiments carried out in 1992 (Bright and Morris 1992)*.
Hedge maintenance and planting Although dormice travel short distances it is hoped that given enough time dormice will spread along hedgerows acting as wildlife corridors between woodlands. The hedges would probably have to be maintained in much the same way as coppices with no flailing or machine cutting and a 15-20 year phased traditional laying regime adhered to. New hedges should be planted to link up habitats; these should be made up predominantly of hazel to provide nuts for dormice prior to hibernation (Bright and Morris 1994) but other tree species must be included to provide food year round for these specialist feeders (Morris 2003).  
Exclusion of grazers and competition. Grazing animals are particularly damaging to shrub layers of woodlands (Bright and Morris 1994). They are damaging to coppice regrowth from cut stools (Peterken 1996) and therefore must be removed, excluded or controlled in areas of dormouse conservation. Squirrels compete indirectly for food with dormice in autumn but do not compete for nest sites (Bright and Morris 1994).
  *This is a particular problem in road widening schemes (a policy that the present government is carrying out nationally) in areas where dormice could once move across the roads by using touching branches within the canopy they now can no longer do so after widening. A dormouse bridge made of a steel gantry filled with brushwood has proved effective in Japan in recent years with dormice nesting in it but it was costly (£100,000) (Morris 2003). An official manual for road construction suggests the use of ropes spanning between trees by the side of the widened road; Morris argues (2003) that dormice will not use this due to increased threat of predation, sagging and exposure to traffic below.   3c. Reintroduction.   Reintroduction involves catching wild dormice from within woodlands where dormice populations are thriving. In captivity they often produce young earlier than wild populations due to the abundance of food. The young are then released back into the wild into woodlands where there are no or low numbers of dormice. The (release) method of dormouse preservation is particularly popular with the general public who are seeking a ‘cure’ for dormouse extinction, (Bright and Morris 1994). However it must be carried out with care due to the complicated nature of these mammals. Animals released at the wrong time and in the wrong way tend to scatter and suffer disorientation and starvation before becoming established (Bright and Morris 1994). Reintroduction has been largely successful; animals have been released into areas where in some cases (Norfolk) dormice have not been recorded since the First World War (Morris 2003). It is very important in helping dormice fill gaps in counties where numbers are thinly spread. Many populations in release areas are showing an increase (Morris 2003), however to be effective in the long term, this release work must be carried out in conjunction with habitat restoration work. It is important that the release sites are chosen with care, as woods of less than 20 hectares are unlikely to sustain dormice populations indefinitely (Morris 2004). De-fragmentation work must be carried out in conjunction with re-introduction of dormice to limit them becoming extinct in these areas in the middle to long term. This is important even in large woodlands that are not linked to other woodlands by wildlife corridors (Bright and Morris 2005). Because dormice live for only 3-5 years, whole populations of even healthy dormice can easily become extinct; for example, three or four wet warm winters could interrupt their hibernation process causing them to be not viable. It is therefore important to look at the large scale landscape structure in relation to species reintroductions and climate change (Bright 1993). Work should be undertaken to assess release sites to test the efficacy of the intended release; this work includes field surveys, construction of computer models and experiments on the role of habitat corridors (Bright 1993).   However, dormice range reduction is not wholly due to habitat fragmentation; one factor may be increasingly unfavourable climate in certain areas. Therefore re-releasing dormice into these areas may not be successful in the long term. Release sites may have a suitable climate now for dormouse survival but may not have in 50 years time.  

Release times of dormice

Dormice must be released at the optimum time of year to ensure their survival  (Bright and Morris 1994). Bright has demonstrated that dormice under a soft release strategy (acclimatised in cages) released in late summer suffer the least body mass change and therefore have the optimum chance of survival (Bright 1993).   Areas for further study. Work is needed in some areas such as at what rate dormice travel along hedgerows and the effect of hedgerow management on the rate of spread. These experiments could include measuring dormice spread along hedgerows undergoing different treatments. High quality hibernation sites may well be more important than nestboxes to ensure the viability of dormice populations (Berg and Berg 1998). More tracking work is needed to show how the quality of winter nest sites affects dormice winter survival rates.   Conclusion. The survey techniques to test for the presence of dormice developed by Morris are an adequate way of testing for presence and legal protection justifies the use of monitoring techniques to ascertain the state of populations. These techniques, especially the use of nestboxes, are very effective in measuring dormice status. Treatments are shown to be site specific and must be adequately monitored to gauge their effectiveness. With dormice under threat in Britain from the changing climate and habitat destruction and fragmentation, the survival of dormice depends on all strands of this article being woven together; without legal protection, more dormouse habitat will be destroyed, without monitoring treatments to woodlands, we can not gauge their effectiveness and without restoration, re-introduction success may is limited.   Appendix A. An overview of the unique traits of the dormouse when compared to other Rodentia.  
  • Dormice belong to their own family of rodents known as Gliridae comprising of about twenty species. Muridae (Mice and rats), on the other hand, have many hundreds of species (Morris 2004).
 
  • Dormice often live 3-5 years, a long lifespan when compared to Microtus arvalis’ (common vole) six month life span (Davis 2002).
 
  • Gliridae have four molar teeth instead of 3 more commonly found in rodents. These teeth last until the end of their lifespan, they will show heavy wear (Yahnke 2004).
 
  • Unlike other rodents dormice tail skin is thin, in the event of being gripped by a predator it will slough off leaving the tailbones exposed (Morris 2004).
 
  • Dormice hind feet are adapted to have gripping pads and are able to rotate backwards at the ankle (like squirrels) allowing them to hang from branches suspended from their hind claws.
 
  • Dormice do not have a caecum and therefore cannot digest leaf material. This has forced M. avellanarius to become a food specialist, something that is contributing to its decline in the U.K.
 
  • They are an ancient form of rodent; fossil records prove that Gliridae were much more abundant than they are today.
    Appendix B. Forestry operations and associated risk to dormice within woodlands.   The level of risk to populations when carrying out forestry operations depends on the following factors (based on information from Natural England/ Forestry Commission Interim Guidance Report 5 Sept 2007):  
  • Size of operation. Coppicing or felling an entire area of forest changes woodland ecology drastically (woodland regresses back through successive stages). This change may not be beneficial to dormice populations who are unable to adapt.
Managing smaller coup sizes minimises ecological impact on the woodland (Kimmins. 1987).  
  • Woodland size. Dormice are under threat of extinction in small isolated woodlands as there is no hope of replenishing the population from the outside (Morris 2003). Small woodlands (less than 10 ha) are more vulnerable to intrusive woodland operations.
 
  • Operation intensity. As mentioned above clearfell operations are more likely to harm dormice populations than thinning operations. However if thinning operations are maintained over a long period of time they can be equally as damaging (for example skidding operations in winter can damage hibernating dormice).
 
  • Habitat structure. Regenerating broadleaf habitat harbours more dormice than dense conifer habitat (See Table 1). Machinery moving through each habitat will affect dormice populations differently, in the former it may be damaging but not lethal (greater population to recover), in the latter it can be disastrous.
 
  • Season of operation. The time period between mid June and August and the hibernation period are perhaps the most damaging times to carry out woodland operations. The period of least damage occurs in April to May, however this coincides with bird nesting season where felling and coppicing should not be carried out. Leaving the coppice to overshadow is not an option as overgrown coppice is not beneficial to dormice populations (Morris 2003).
      References.   Anon. (2007). Guidance on managing woodlands with dormice in England. Interim Guidance, Version 2, September 2007. Natural England/Forestry Commission.   Begon M., Harper J.
