item.title: Management of plantations on ancient woodland sites. (paper)
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded:
Antony Lucas, Bsc. Hons (Ecology), FdSc. (Forestry and Woodland Management). Tech ArborA. Here is an extract of a larger article concerning the management of recently planted coniferous sites in Britain. NOTE. figs and diagrams missing. Restoration of Plantations on Ancient Woodland Sites (PAWS) to native broadleaf forests in the United Kingdom.  

Wildwood in the British Isles, a brief history.

  Recent analysis of ice cores from the polar icecaps and from deep sea ocean cores suggest that there have been up to eight periods of polar ice cap growth and retreat (T. Darvil 2000). The last of these periods of polar expansion (known as the Devensian Glaciation) ended in around 9000 BC (T. Darvil 2000). The bare land left by glacial retreats were colonised by lichens and mosses that eventually formed soils that could support vascular plants (Rackham 1976). Successive stages of vegetation continued until c.8000 BC at which time, an advanced wooded landscape existed throughout The British Isles. Oliver Rackham termed this landscape as ‘wildwood’- ‘a self-regenerative woodland which is highly variable in density and cover’. (Rackham 1976). Woodlands were systematically destroyed for farming from the late Neolithic Age  (4000 B.C.) (Pryor 2000) indeed by 1350 AD total woodland area in England had shrunk to 10 percent of the land area, a destruction of an average of 17.5 acres a day (Rackham 1986, 2000). The situation broadly continued until the 1700s. At this time silvicultural practices were being widely adopted for the first time, mainly for building ships for England’s burgeoning navy.  

Ancient Semi Natural Woodland Sites (ASNWS) and Plantations on Ancient Woodland Sites (PAWS).

  In England, Ancient Woodland is considered to be land that was first recorded as woodland in AD 1600. It was at this time that the first conclusive land surveys were carried out (Lucas 2007), it was also after this time that plantations were being established. Dr Rackham claimed in 1976 that woodlands recorded at this date were probably wooded back into pre-history and in some cases may well be remnants of the Wildwood. These Ancient Semi Natural Woodlands (ASNWs) may not have always been continuously wooded; often these woodland sites have been felled and re-grown many times (Rackham 1976). In recent times, the vast majority of ASNW broadleaf woodlands have been felled to have their tree stock replaced by plantations of conifer between the years 1941-1970 (S.N Pryor et al 2002), these plantations are commonly known as Plantations on Ancient Woodland Sites (PAWS).* Due to the rich diversity of species and ecological associations within ASNWs they are considered to be of high ecological and environmental importance (Peterken 1996). PAWS may often retain some of their original genetic seed stock and some of the characteristics of Ancient Woodlands and many sites have the potential for successful restoration back to native woodlands (Forestry Commission Wales 2007) this is because many of the features of the original ASNW are extant (S.N Pryor et al 2002). In probability, if conifer plantations on PAWS are felled (over time) a semblance of the original woodland may regenerate. (Lucas 2007).   *By 2002, approximately 44% of the ancient woodland in Britain had been converted to plantation, a figure that gives around 220,000 ha of PAWS (S.N Pryor et al 2002).   Current objectives, policy and management activities.   The introduction of the broadleaves policy in 1985 began to reverse this trend, (Goldman 2003) and this coupled with a substantial fall in the profitability of softwood timber production in the U.K. set the scene for management change. This change in the market, time of rotation of final crop and greater interest in amenity value of woodlands enabled policy to shift to restoration of PAWS (S.N Pryor et al 2002). The U.K. B.A.P. includes plans to restore substantial areas of PAWS to native woodland by 2020. In order to achieve this goal however, landowners are being encouraged to clearfell or heavily thin all existing conifers and replant the sites with native broadleaf species (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). Conventional clearfell is now being used on a minority of sites but there is still widespread emphasis on rapid restoration, both in crop removal and restocking  (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). This practice may not be the best way of restoring PAWS sites and in many cases this practice can cause a major disturbance to the conditions of a site. This disturbance can have disastrous effects on woodland ecology (S.N Pryor et al 2002). At the time of writing (2007), there are very attractive grants of up to £2000 per ha from the forestry commission to encourage landowners (in Wales) to clearfell coniferous plantations and replant with native broadleaf trees. (Forestry Commission Wales, ‘Better Woodlands for Wales’, 28th Jan 2007). Practice guides on PAWS restoration published by the forestry commission encourage this management practice with a few caveats, namely site surveys.   Ecological principles of Restoration of PAWS Sites. Many PAWS contain relict communities and ecological features of the original ASNW woodland (Peterken 1996). These remnants are the remainder of the ASNW flora and (in some cases) fauna that created the unique climactic make up of species that arose through competitive exclusion of many years (Gause 1934), (Rackham 1976). Remnants of ancient woodland flora plants are often mutualist and specialist types that rely on late stage woodland features such as dead wood habitats or undisturbed soil conditions, despite the soil being disturbed by the felling of the ASNW site and subsequent soil changes due to coniferisation. The areas in which they can persist include topographical features such as outcrops, ravines or steep slopes (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). and rides and clearings (Goldman 2003). They harbour the seeds that contain the genetic continuity from the original ASNW and trees surrounding these should be carefully managed. These areas are even more important because woodland specialist plants do not generally have long lived seed and therefore may be absent from these seed banks, especially if the plant can not survive in vegetative form (S.N. Pryor et al 2002).   The forestry commission definition of a PAWS site has a species mix of over 50% conifer (Forestry Commission 2007). To take 50 to 100 percent of trees out of any woodland can be disastrous to the conditions and resources of any site let alone one that has been already been recently changed. It is these conditions and resources that define individual flora or fauna population niches within the site. As ASNW or PAWS, communities are of predominantly woodland types, removal of tree cover on a site will cause disruption to the existing ecology. For most existing woodland species, realised and fundamental niches are reduced during clearfell because of changes in the available conditions and resources, some plants or animals could disappear entirely. Guilds between animals and plants, parasitical relationships, saprophytical relationships and mutualistic relationships such Michorizal associations can be disastrously affected by changes in conditions resources, niche and resultant food web disruptions.   Even if there are wildlife corridors to other similar woodlands, as the site recovers and tree cover increases, many disrupted species will find it difficult to return. This is because many woodland flora types are sedentary and will only colonise by vegetative spread, indeed, (in woodland) under current climatic conditions some species can only move at a few metres per century (S.N. Pryor et al 2002).     Condition change by clearfell or heavy thinning regimes. Begon, Harper and Townsend define conditions as: ‘an abiotic environmental factor which varies in space and time, and to which organisms are differentially responsive’ (Begon et al. 1986,1990). These conditions cannot be used up, one organisms loss may be another organisms gain, each organism, species and community has a different set of tolerances. Clearfell will change the conditions of a site. Therefore a ‘continuous cover’ system is likely to suit the majority of woodland specialists and woodland interior species   (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). A simplified list of general change in conditions on the clearfelled site is summarised below.   Water. The water cycle can be altered to create more damp soils and drier soils; on upland sites clearfell leads to a reduction in total stream flow (Kimmins 1987).   Temperature. Sunlight on surface layer of cleared area increases temperature during the day, however a lack of cover decreases temperature at night and increases chance of frost within cleared area.   Relative humidity. Relative humidity decreases during the day in clearfelled area. Deadwood habitats dessicate. Affects epiphytes, bryophytes fungi and invertebrate populations (S.N. Pryor et al 2002).  Resulting in food web and energy flow change on the site.   Light Fungi communities are negatively affected by desiccation caused by increased sunlight caused by intensive tree felling (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). Flora responds to this conditional change by encouraging light tolerant species to dominate.   Soil pH. Due to podsolisation, Soil pH was lowered (in most areas) changing from ASNW to PAWS, this may reverse.   Disturbance and consequent succession. The disturbance of the site by clearfelling or heavy thinning the entire area, even with some refugia can be intense. Experiments such as schemes in Sherwood forest have proved that sudden exposure of veteran trees by removing conifers has resulted in their death or rises in the water table that have introduced different ground flora (Goldberg 2003). Veteran trees are particularly important on PAWS, not only because of they contain remnants of the original seed bank but also because they can contain habitats that are suitable for epiphytes, fungi, bats, invertebrates and birds (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). It is not just veteran trees that can suffer: many late succession stage woodland vascular plants could be described as ‘comfortable’, they are adapted to relatively undisturbed environments; they often have a ‘general stress tolerator’ strategy (this is similar in terms to a k strategy where organisms are adapted to stable conditions) (S.N. Pryor et al 2002).  Plants with this strategy are at a great disadvantage when adapting to changes in conditions such as desiccation and loss of habitat. Clearfell then is likely to put them at a competitive disadvantage in relation to existing r selected species such as Rubus fruticosus. More r selected species colonisation occurs from outside the site, these tree species are at an advantage on recently cleared ground because they are ones that produce propagules regularly and copiously and ones that disperse them far and rapidly (Peterken 1996) Newly planted trees are at a disadvantage to incomers for planted trees are often k selected species (lowland types such as oak), however, both of these will be at a disadvantage to the r selected incomers and the more robust natural regeneration from the original seed bank (Battles et al., 2001). The effect of this is that the clear felling has caused the successive stages of the woodland to be reversed to the stage of the first pioneer tree species (see Fig. 1).   Fig. 1. Simplified diagram of floral successive stages (SEREs) within PAWS site during clearfell process. SERE1 BARE EARTH After glacial retreat   SERE 2 Lichens and Moss Colonise   SERE 3 Grasses   SERE 4(a)                                         SERE 4(b) R Selected Trees                               Coniferous Plantation   SERE 5 (a).                                        SERE 5 (b). k selected trees develop                    Coniferous Plantation Succeeding r. SERE 6 (a). Climax temperate woodland   Fig 1. Demonstrates the inappropriate plan of trying to jump from Sere 5(b) to Sere 6.   Nutrient cycle and food web. Clearfelled trees are often removed from the forest, therefore most of the biomass is taken from the woodland site. This ‘clearing up’ not only reduces deadwood habitats for saprophytes, it affects all decomposers and detritivores. The woodland food web is disrupted by the change in conditions and resources and although the trophic levels of the food web remain in place, the types of consumers on each level may change. Competition between animals in small pockets of remaining woodland increases and if wildlife corridors are non-existent to other woodlands, animals crossing open ground are prone to predation by carnivores in the higher trophic levels of the food web.  
Alternative methods of PAWS reversion management. The UK BAP guidelines of restoring PAWS sites by 2020 could be detrimental the remnants of ASNW ecology existing PAWS sites and does not allow for a more measured, longer term strategy of management. The overall aim of PAWS restoration work is not to re-create unaltered ASNWs, this would be un-realistic, it is however, an opportunity to conserve and enhance remnants of ancient woodland communities and to create ‘restored native woodland on ancient sites’ (RNWAS) (S.N. Pryor, et al 2002). The aim therefore should be to “manipulate the canopy to create the conditions in which remnant ASNW communities can recover” (S.N. Pryor et al 2002) and also to realise that “in the medium to long term that conifers (will be) incorporated into the stand structure, that some unwanted regeneration is tolerated and that a more flexible approach is taken to broadleaves such as beech, sweet chestnut and sycamore” (S.N. Pryor et al 2002).   Recommendations. The first recommendation is that a careful study of the existing ASNW vegetation, deadwood habitats and associated communities be carried out for each individual site. These ‘hotspots of relative abundance should be recorded and these areas given special treatment depending on their ecological conditions, resources and preferences. These areas provide a diversity of habitat niches and can be of geomorphological interest (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). These areas can be sensitively opened up by thinning out the over shadowing coniferous overstorey, This thinning must be carefully undertaken particularly because from the perspective of ASNW communities (particularly ground flora), even small coup thinnings can effect them in the same way as clearfell  (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). Rides can be opened up by thinning out trees sensitively and the whole woodland can be thinned in a series of thinning operations using a selection system with a preference for any native trees within the stand. It is preferable that these trees be selected for wind-firmness where conditions allow and areas around the edge of the woodland thinned more where semi natural elements are concentrated (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). The overall aim of this selection system would be to provide a more varied stand structure without damaging or denuding ASNW ground flora (for canopy density and ground flora survival scores, see fig. 3). This will increase biodiversity within the stand because all structures and age classes should be present with in the woods (Peterken 1996).    
Canopy Cover
Dense 90%+
Closed 60-90%
Gappy 30-60%
Open 30% and less
  Fig.3. shows that even under a gappy or closed canopy ground flora has a better survival rate than when the trees are removed from the site.   Recolonisation and restocking. PAWS sites that are isolated from other ASNWS will find it difficult to be re-colonised by plants and animals and where there are existing sites re-colonisation will be slow (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). In these cases it may be that only wind pollinated species (such as Betula ssp.) will re-colonise the site, however these species combined with planting of preferred site specific native broadleaf trees should create a diverse tree mixture. It may be necessary to replant, remove or re-space any natural regeneration on the site. Given enough time (and with the right silvicultural system), an even-aged stand of trees can be replaced with an un-even aged stand. After careful thinning operations the last of the PAWS trees are removed leaving a structurally diverse RNWAS. Natural regeneration should be favoured over re-planting, however to achieve re-stocking targets for grant aid planting density of 1100 stems per hectare is anticipated. Reliance on grants can seriously limit the type of silvicultural system to be employed and re-planting often involves herbicide applications, which may cause further losses to relict ASNW flora (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). Even in re-establishment of Wood Pasture systems, grazers must be excluded from the newly thinned site, as they will browse on any germinating trees and ground flora from the original ASNW seed bank.   The site must be constantly monitored and a woodland management plan must be flexible to take into account and deal with any changes or problems that may occur (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). Management of the site in this way is more costly, more arduous and involves much more thought than the clearfell method but can be more beneficial to the biodiversity and age diversity of the RNWAS  (S.N. Pryor et al. 2002).    

Discussion

Many ASNWS have been felled many times and re-grown, often with different species replacing the previous species mix, (Peterken 1996). Species mixtures in ASNWS change over time (even with little interference from man) (see Peterken, Natural Woodland, 1996. p.359 Core Samples From Ridley Wood, New Forest). Is it acceptable to think of ASNWs as being in stasis rather than being in a state of flux? The main problem with current PAWS restoration policy is that it pre-supposes that woodland species make up does not change and uses knee jerk sylvicultural systems in order to quickly re-create an un-obtainable past idyll. This ‘idyll’ may come again for some PAWS sites, however, as with most endeavours in the discipline of forestry, one has to learn to make plans now even though we may never see their fruition. The PAWS restoration problem presents a great opportunity to advance alternative sylvicultural systems in the U.K.   Applicable use of Clearfell Systems and non intervention strategies. Some woodland communities are more adapted to changeable conditions such as coppice with standards and Caledonian Pine Forests. Many species of Lepidoptera and thicket stage birds are dependent on open ground and therefore, in some cases clearfell may be an option for restoring ASNWS.  (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). On PAWS sites, original ASNW ground flora remains largely unchanged under certain species of conifer such as pine and larch (S.N. Pryor et al 2002). This has implications on work being hurried by the time periods set by the UK BAP guidelines. In these cases perhaps non-intervention could be considered until the end of the timber rotation of the site.   References. Agate Elizabeth, 1980-2005, Woodlands, a Practical Handbook, BTCV Publications.   Battles J.J.,  Shlisky, A.L., Barret, R.H., Heald, R.C., Allen-Diaz, B.H. (2001) The effects of forest management on plant species diversity in a Sierran conifer forest. Forest Ecology and Management, 146, 211-222.   Begon, Michael. Harper, John L. Townsend, Colin R. 1986, 1990 Ecology: Individuals, populations and Communities. Blackwell Science Editorial Offices, 238 Main St. Cambridge, Massachusetts. 02142 USA.   Broad Ken, 1998, 1999, Caring for Small Woods, Earthscan Publications Ltd.   Darvil, Timothy, 2000. Prehistoric Britain. Routledge. 11 New Fetter Lane, London. EC4P 4EE   Goldberg, Emma. 2003. Plantations on Ancient Woodland Sites, Quarterly Journal of Forestry, No.97, April 2003 vol.2, p.133-138.   Lucas, Antony. 2007, Ancient Semi Natural Woodlands, TPOs and Felling Licence Assignment, Plumpton College.   Pryor, S.N. Curtis, T.A. Peterken G.F. 2002. Woodland Trust Guide: Restoring Plantations on Ancient Woodland Sites, Conversion to Native Woodland or Conversion to Ancient Woodland Communities, Oxford Forestry Institute.   Pryor, Francis. 2003. Britain B.C. Harper and Collins.   Rackham Oliver, 1976, Trees and Woodland in the British Landscape, Aldine Press Letchworth Herts.   Rackham Oliver, 1986,2000, The History of the Countryside, Orion Publishing Group Ltd.

item.title: Scots Pine distribution in relation to climate change (paper).
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded:
Antony Lucas, Bsc. Hons (Ecology), FdSc. (Forestry and Woodland Management). Tech ArborA. European distribution of Pinus sylvestris. The following is an extract of a paper concerning Pinus sylvestris distribution, past and present and its possible distribution in relation to climate change. NOTE many diagrams have been removed.   Introduction. Flora and fauna species are not evenly distributed over the surface of the earth, they display regional differences, these differences can be grouped together to form six biogeographical regions (Sclater 1858). Some groups of species are endemic to one region and some share biogeographical regions (Hugget 1998). Each region can contract and expand in area as species are affected by climate changes. Within each region, there is variability in climatic and biotic factors at a micro, local, regional and national scale, it is this, along with many other factors that determines species distribution. P. sylvestris is a sub arctic tree species that occurs in the northerly Palaearctic bio-region (Hugget 1998). Its northern limit is around 70 degrees 22’N in Norway, the southern limit is around 37 degrees N in southern Spain. The eastern limit is near the Pacific Ocean 138 degrees E and the western limit is at 5 degrees 38’W in Scotland (Carlisle and Brown 1958). Generally speaking, P. sylvestris is an adaptable species found most abundantly in the drier eastern districts of Europe, (Savill 1991) however in the U.K., outliers of its present range in Scotland represent the only remaining natural woodland. (Savill 1991, Rodwell 1991, Peterken 1996, Provan et al. 1998). Their area is small however, total coverage here being only 11000ha. (Provan et al. 1998). In many areas P. sylvestris has become extinct in the last 10 000 years (since the last ice age). P. sylvestris has been commercially planted, but natural P. sylvestris woodlands tend to have remnants of moorland ground flora rather than woodland flora due to herbivorous grazing (Summers et al. 1988). However, there are some woodland specialists associated with P. sylvestris woodlands and ground flora is often rich in bryophytes, (a basis for sub division in the NVC guides) (Rodwell 1991, Rackham 2006). Historically it is this association with open vegetation and its ‘r’ selected strategy that has allowed it to rapidly colonise areas of previously tree-free terrain under the right conditions.       Factors affecting species or communities distribution with particular reference to P.sylvestris.   Dispersal   The ease and rate of dispersal of a species depends on two factors, the topography and the climate of the terrain over which species are attempting to disperse (Hugget 1998). Species generally have three main distributional patterns:  
  • Large or small
  • Widespread or restricted
  • Continuous or broken.
  Limits to dispersal can include physical boundaries such as mountains, oceans, deserts or any condition such as a climatic factor that is outside a species tolerance range. It is thought that species that are adapted to living at higher latitudes such as P. sylvestris are less sensitive to barriers to dispersal as they are more tolerant of harsher conditions such as those conditions created by the Pliestocene Ice Ages. Conversely species in the tropics will find it more difficult to adapt to harsher conditions and will be more sedentary in nature (Hugget 1998). Often climate and topography change so that a species may suffer extinction over much of its previous range contracting to small pockets or relict groups that survive, isolated from other groups.   Tolerances.   For each environmental variable, there is a lower and upper limit to a species’ tolerance to it; for example P. sylvestris is tolerant of poor soils (Rackham 2006), does not like potassium deficiency (Carlisle and Brown 1958) and will not normally occur on calcareous soils or peaty acidic soils (Savill 1991), it has a range of pH of soil it can inhabit with a preferential optimum. A simple graph can be plotted to discover the ecological valency of each species where environmental factors are included to find their optimum condition (See fig. 2). Many species desire similar conditions and provided there is niche separation, they will co-exist. All species have distributional boundary edges in relation to climate which halt their expansion, such as frost line and tree line association with altitude. These winter temperatures and a lack of available moisture exert a strong hold on species distributions. (Hugget 1998). However, P. sylvestris prefer chilling for germination, temperature is a factor that positively affects growth at higher altitudes (Grace and Norton 1990), (optimum growth temperature is 18.5 degrees C) (Carlisle and Brown 1958). This explains in part why this species is found in bands of colonisation at higher latitudes/altitudes (Savill1991) above the broadleaf forest tree line. (Carlisle and Brown 1958).   P. sylvestris can tolerate a wide range of climatic conditions from the near tundra of Siberia to the Mediterranean climate of southern Spain. It can withstand the wet climate of the Atlantic coast of Scotland to the dry conditions of Central Europe and Asia (Carlisle and Brown 1958). Northerly limits of the species are probably controlled by temperature; P. sylvestris can withstand temperatures down to -26.7 degrees. The southerly limit is probably similar in that it is not found where temperatures exceed 26.7 degrees C. This may be due to an imbalance between photosynthesis and respiration at higher temperatures (Carlisle and Brown 1958). The zonation of biomes in the altitudinal gradient is broadly similar to vegetation changes in the lateral gradient; as one goes higher, vegetation changes as a response to environmental changes (Cox 2000) until there is a point where conditions are too harsh for a species to be viable (Cox 2000).   Elevation, aspect and slope inclination can determine the distribution of species at local and regional scales. P. sylvestris woodland would be found in the needletree layer and will not thrive at higher altitudes unless there is adequate topographic shelter (Savill 1991) as wind, frost and snow damage are responsible with frost for causing fatalities at higher altitudes/latitudes (Carlisle and Brown 1958). Fig. 3 shows clear delineations between species but often at the edges of each layer the species are in direct competition. P. sylvestris is a climax forest vegetation on many nutrient-deficient sites but will lose out in direct competition with other conifers such as  Picea abies  (Tofts 1988). Betula sp. on the other hand tends to give way to it where there is direct competition. This competition influences species distribution because it is another limiting factor. Limiting factors may not necessarily be lethal for a species; they may just limit species’ range by influencing viability (Cox 2000).   Ice ages and past P. sylvestris dispersal and distribution.   Patterns of distribution of species are mainly controlled by geography and climate, these factors change over time. Conditions were different in the past and it has been shown that patterns of distribution were also different (Cox 2000). Studies of past distributions of P. sylvestris  are important as they show areas of past refugia and tell us how a species is likely to be distributed in future (Garzon et al. 2007). The species  is part of a belt of red pines that spans the subarctic regions of the northern hemisphere. Those in the Far East and America are now of a different species, however these still retain many similar characteristics (Rackham 2008). During previous interglacial periods P. sylvestris would have been distributed much as they are today, predominantly in Northern Europe and Asia with a few refuges south of the Alps and Pyrenees. However with the advance of ice sheets in Europe during the Pleistocene P. sylvestris distributions would have contracted south to rely on those individuals that had existed at the southern edge of their distribution. Many now common northern European plant species would have been considered climatic relicts during the last glacial expansion in these areas (Carlisle and Brown 1958). However, after the last glacial retreat 10000 years ago, P. sylvestris  became the most dominant tree in Europe. The species travelled northwards from  remnant communities south of the ice sheets in areas such as the Iberian Peninsula, Greece, The Balkans and Turkey (Garzon 2007, Pyhajarvi 2008). They achieved this faster and further through Europe than other tree species through wind pollination and active dispersal (Hugget 1998).  In this way P. sylvestris along with other temperate pioneer, r selected species quickly claimed land that had previously been tundra or had been effectively scoured of vegetation by ice. In most of Europe P. sylvestris was displaced by waves of other trees species such as hazel, elm, oak and alder. In Britain the last native invader to arrive was the small leafed lime before Britain became cut off from mainland Europe in around 5500 BC this meant that the P. sylvestris was genetically isolated in Scotland until continental strains were inyroduced in the middle ages. Some areas of Europe remained ideal for P. sylvestris woodland but as a whole the distribution contracted as the species’ fundamental niche gave way to its realised niche. P. sylvestris at this time, extended to higher altitudes and further north in Europe than at present (Grace and Norton 1990). However, cooler, wetter weather systems restricted these expansions by peat bog formation especially in the west of Scotland. (Rackham 2006). Tree stumps have been found and radio carbon dated above the present tree line in Scotland showing a contraction of range in altitude since the last glacial retreat.   Fragmentation   Competition with other species, the collapse of the land bridge from Britain to mainland Europe and the warming of the climate in the southern areas all caused degrees of fragmentation for P. sylvestris. Patches, corridors and matrixes remained where there was once a continuous population (Hugget 1998). Anthropogenic factors such as forestry and agriculture lead to further fragmentation of plant species (Cox 2001). It is notable that P. sylvestris does not coppice, therefore any felling of trees by Mesolithic people onwards would not be replaced especially if the felling regime involved felling larger trees for fuel and subsequent clearance by fire  (Savill 1991). Today, in the isolated island group of The Caledonian Pine Forest, grazing and lack of fire management has led to a cessation of expansion of many native pine woodlands (Palmer and Truscott 2003, Rackham 2006).  Although sizes of individual trees were found to be greater in ancient woodlands, density however was 10 times less. This disparity of area size and numbers of individuals could lead to genetic impoverishment by dense planted European strain plantations (Kinloch et al 1986).     Speciation.   Geographical isolation reduces or halts gene flow because it isolates individuals from a once continuous population. If isolated for a long period each population will develop into different species, in its most basic form (where two species are isolated) this is known as this is known as allopatric speciation (Hugget 1998). Speciation occurs because natural selection takes place independently in each population of a species, adapting it to local conditions.  If isolation continues a new species may develop (Cox 2000). Speciation between P. sylvestris and other red pines probably occurred during the Mid-Miocine when there was an expansion of gymnosperms in the northern hemisphere  (Cox 2000). Adaptation has already been taking place since the last ice age in P. sylvestris. Groups growing in northern latitudes often have shorter leaves than the same species in southern climes; this is thought to be an adaptation to frost damage (Carlisle and Brown 1958). The Iberian populations are a distinct sub species, genetically different from those of the rest of Europe (Garzon et al 2007). Some studies suggest that these populations are of their own evolutionary line because they have survived on the peninsula, unable to re-colonise the rest of Europe because of the Pyrenees barrier (Garzon et al 2007). Both the Caledonian Forest and the Iberian group are important areas for conservation because they are geographically isolated from each other allowing many species to form distinct (and less distinct) sub-species (Provan et. Al 1998, Garzon et al. 2007). Therefore the author theorises that if left long enough and under the right conditions P. sylvestris in Scotland could become a separate species from P. sylvestris on the Iberian Peninsula.   The genetic distribution of P. sylvestris.   Looking at the genetics of P. sylvestris populations can tell us about how they have achieved present distribution and how different two apparently similar groups of P. sylvestris are. There are innumerable sub species of Pinus sylvestris from Spain to Siberia (Rackham 2006). Threats to Caledonian native British Scots pines (Pinus sylvestris subsp. Scotica) and the Iberian Peninsula group are thought to be due to fragmentation and a reduction of areas size because they are both at the limits of the species’ distributional range . (Peterken,1996, Garzon et al. 2007). Studies carried out by Kinloch et al. (1986) showed that Scottish populations are not genetically impoverished in spite of the large contraction of range and individuals and that  the variability in these populations was among the highest found in any plant populations (Kinloch et al 1986). There was little similarity between Scottish populations and European populations. Furthermore the results of genetic tests and the pollen distribution within the Holocene showed that the Scottish population of P. sylvestris originated from more than one refugial population after the last ice age (Kinloch et al 1986). However, more recent studies carried out by Provan et al. (1998) have shown there is no significant genetic difference between most of the Scottish and European types although there was evidence of a population substructure in the Loch Rannoch region which had two subgroups (this was thought to be due to the woodland being planted with seeds favoured for their phenotypes) (Provan et al. 1998). There was evidence of a mutation in the Wester Ross region, this has occurred fairly recently or may be evidence of a refuge for this species during the last ice age (Provan et al. 1998).  The refuge would not have been at its present location however. The lowest genetic diversity was shown in the Glen Falloch population showing a severe depletion in the genetic base (Provan et al. 1998). More work is required in this and other areas of Europe to establish a map of genetic diversity for P. sylvestris.     Climate change and Future P. sylvestris distribution.   As global temperatures warm P. sylvestris as a species will be required to move its range north or and higher in altitude. Evidence of this is already occurring; the entire P. sylvestris population increased in northern Sweden by 50% in a recent 32 year study and therefore became the most dominant tree in the landscape. This reverses a millennial trend of decline in population (Kullman 2007). P. sylvestris can act as an indicator of the Palearctic biome moving into the tundra biome. The tundra biome may be particularly vulnerable to a warming of the global climate because there is no land area for vegetation and animal species to retreat further north and it is in this area that there is the greatest rise in temperature (Kullman 2007). P. sylvestris is known as a timberline species (Savill 1991) therefore there is likely to be rapid decrease in areas suitable for P. Sylvestris as the species shifts up the altitudinal gradient as a response to climate change. Evidence has shown that in both Finland and Scotland P. sylvestris tree lines have risen (Grace and Norton 1990). This shift will influence patch size, shape and edginess, these are all important factors in determining species richness (Hugget 1998). Iberian Peninsula groups will be forced to shift to the higher mountains of the Pyrenees and are therefore likely to disappear from southern and central mountainous areas (See Fig. 1.) (Garzon  et al. 2007).   Fig. 1. Change in area in the past and in the future of P. sylvestris on the Iberian Peninsula in relation to the present. After Garzon et al. 2007).  
Maintained Expanded Reduced
KM2 % KM2 % KM2 %
4000BC 16755 51.9 2718 8.4 15781 48.9
19000BC 4043 12.5 5146 15.9 28553 88.4
 2080AD 401 1.2 535 1.7 31841 98.6
  Fig. 1 demonstrates that as the P. sylvestris area of occupation increases so does its altitudinal range in the mountains. There is a predicted contraction of range for P. Sylvestris in the Iberian Peninsula of 90% by the year 2080. The species is expected to disappear from the Iberian peninsula within the next 100 years, resulting in the end of the genetic pool of the Iberian P. sylvestris which had survived through the previous glacial events (Garzon et al 2007).   References. Carlisle. A. Brown, A. (1958) Biological Flora of the British Isles. Pinus sylvestris L. L.C. vol.11 no.2255, pp.260 -283. Cox, B. (2000) Biogeography, An Ecological and Evolutionary Approach. Blackwell Science. Eggleton P. Vanbergen, A. Jones, D. Lambert, M. Rockett, C. Hammond, P. Beccaloni, J. Marriott, D. Ross, E. Guisti, A. (2005). Assemblages of soil macrofauna across a Scottish land use intensification gradient: influences of habitat quality heterogeneity and area. Journal of Applied Ecology Vol.42, pp.1153-1164. Garzon, M. Sanchez de Dios, R. Ollero, H. (2007)  The evolution of the Pinus sylvestris L. Area in the Iberian Peninsula from the last glacial maximum to 2100 under climate change.. The Holocene 18,5 pp.705-714. Grace, J. Norton, D. (1990) Climate and growth of Pinus sylvestris at its upper altitudinal limit in Scotland: evidence from tree growth rings. Journal of Ecology. Vol.78. pp.601-610 Hugget, R. (1998)  Fundamentals of Biogeography Routeledge. Kinloch, B. Westfall, R. Forrest, G. (1986) Caledonian Scots pine: Origins and genetic structure.  The New Phytologist. Vol. 104 pp. 703-729. Kullman, L. (2007) Tree line population monitoring of Pinus sylvestris in the Swedish Scandes, 1973-2005: implications for tree line theory and climate change ecology. Journal of Ecology. Vol. 95, pp. 41-52. Palmer, S. Truscott. M. (2003) Browsing by deer on naturally regenerating Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris L.) and its effects on sapling growth. Forestry  Ecology and Management. Vol. 182, Issues 1-3, 3 September 2003, P. 31-47. Palmer, S. Broadhead, J. Ross, I. Smith, D. item.title: The Hobbit Wood Burning Stove
item.dc:creator: tonylucas
item.content:encoded:
We are proud to be an approved supplier of 'The Hobbit' wood burning stove - a small cast iron stove with airwash and cleanburn - £485rrp inc VAT. Designed by engineers and handmade by craftsmen, this little cast iron multi fuel stove is at the pinnacle of stove design. Compact proportions make it the ideal choice for a canal boat. The Hobbit incorporates patented turboblaze technology, ensuring excellent clean burning and glass airwash efficiency. The dual turboblaze secondary combustion chambers fitted inside each hobbit stove ensure that the maximum energy potential of every log or lump of coal is harnessed. Hobbit Installations can include a variety of scenarios and the compact nature of the stove makes it ideal for stove installations where space is restricted. The stove is a complimentary blend of traditional elegance and modern styling. The clean lines making it suitable for a wide range of decor situations. Many traditional small fireplaces, especially those converted to gas, need widening to incorporate a wood stove. The small footprint of the Hobbit means that this stove can be installed into a small fireplace without the need for remedial building works. The Hobbit is a multi fuel stove that will deliver a reliable heat source with an accurate degree of control, economy and environmental awareness. The components of each stove are made using the stove makers material of choice, cast iron. Steel bodied stoves may heat up faster but fail to retain the heat and will cool off quickly.
  • Heat Output : 4Kw
  • Flue Size : 100mm
  • Height : 465mm
  • Width : 302mm
  • Depth 272mm
  • Efficiency : 75%
  • Multifuel : Yes
  • Airwash : Yes
  • Clean burn : Yes
  • Cast Iron : Yes
  • EN Approved S.C Areas
  The materials used in every Hobbit stove offer the best in strength, versatility and durability. The throat plate can be easily removed to allow cleaning of the stove and flue without the inconvenience of removing other internal parts. The body of every stove is guaranteed for 12 years and all non-consumable parts are guaranteed for 5 years. This makes the guarantee the best on the market today. Every Hobbit stove whilst small in proportion has been rigorously designed, built and tested to comply with EN13240:2001 ensuring the best efficiency and incorporates the latest clean burning and air-wash technology. This means when burning either wood or coal the picture window not only stays clear but emissions and ash deposits are reduced. Hobbit stoves may be small but each has the power to extract every ounce of effective heat from the fuel used. Delivered to your door within 7 days - Please email or telephone 0789413869 for more information and we will be pleased to answer any questions.
